title: alastantiger
author: alastantiger
content: One of the major security issues affecting permissionless proof-of-stake (PoS) blockchains is long-range attacks (LRA), also called posterior corruption attacks. An attack based on the inability of a user who disconnects from the system at time t1 and reconnects at a later time to tell that validators who were legitimate at time t1 and left the system (for example, by transferring their stake to another validator or by assuming a different identity) are no longer trustworthy. Since PoS systems do not require physical resources like energy for the creation of blocks (i.e., are not time-limited), these validators could create forks that start from t1, and run up until the present. It differs sharply from proof-of-work (PoW) systems, in which creating blocks involves time (for instance, Bitcoin difficulty adjustment) as well as physical resources (for example, energy for computation itself) rather than just cryptographic keys. Because clients of a PoS blockchain are presented with a “valid” chain fork, they will not be able to identify the attack.  In order to prevent this attack on a PoS chain, these researchers proposed a protocol that checkpoints the chain's state to a proof-of-work blockchain, such as Bitcoin. With Schnorr signatures and Bitcoin's Taproot upgrade, they were able to create a constant-size checkpointing transaction. The checkpoints becomes constant in the size of PoS validators and indistinguishable from any other Taproot’s transaction. Although, there is still work to be done but this is the only checkpointing protocol that is not dependent on any central authority.
